DOC.HEAD: Group Declares Opposition in Soviet Congress
DOC.TEXT: A leading reformer said Thursday that scores of members of the Congress of People's Deputies have been forced into opposition by the majority's unwillingness to press reforms. The declaration by historian Yuri N. Afanasyev was a watered-down version of a statement first debated a week ago by the Inter-Regional Deputies Group, proclaiming a ``political opposition'' to the Communist Party and government. Still, it set the 2,250-member Congress on a stormy debate. Afanasyev called for an end to the Communist Party's monopoly on power, and criticized the congress for failing to take up key questions of economic reform. ``We are in the opposition to the decisions of the Congress,'' Afanasyev said. ``We can't agree with indefinite postponement of the passage of the most important laws.'' The Inter-Regional Group failed on the opening day of the Congress Dec. 12 to place on the agenda the party's constitutional role as the ``leading and guiding force'' of Soviet society. It also failed to put on the agenda a discussion of laws on land, property, and economic organization. Afanasyev said he spoke for at least 130 members of the Inter-Regional Deputies Group, which includes about 400 Congress members. The group had included human rights activist Andrei D. Sakharov, who died last Thursday after attending a meeting in which the group discussed declaring a formal opposition. Svyatoslav Medvedev, a deputy from northern Kazakhstan, charged in a congress debate that Afanasyev's group ``has started an open struggle for political power in the country.'' Afanasyev has said formation of a formal opposition to the Communist Party and government could be a step toward formation of an opposition political party. He has declared his support for a multiparty system.
